newsitem.title: indonesia: Japan's Jakarta embassy gets second bomb threat.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Jakarta embassy gets second bomb threat.

text.p: Indonesian police searched the Japanese embassy in Jakarta on Wednesday after the second telephoned bomb threat to the mission in eight days, but they said no explosives were found.
"We found no bomb in the compound. Things are clear there," an official at the local police station said.
Some embassy members had been cleared from the main building while police and mission staff searched the area.
A policeman inside the embassy compound said an anonymous caller had telephoned the switchboard at 9.25 a.m. (0225 GMT) and said there was a bomb in the building. The caller then hung up.

The embassy, on a main throughfare through Jakarta's central business district, was evacuated following a hoax telephoned bomb threat on Wednesday last week on the eve of Indonesia's general elections.
Japanese sources said it was not clear if the two calls were made by the same person.
Diplomatic sources said they were unable to explain why the Japanese embassy was being targetted.

The main strain in relations between Indonesia and Japan at the moment is a complaint by Tokyo -- alongside the United States and the European Union -- to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) over Jakarta's national car policy.

Indonesia has given tax and tariff breaks to a company headed by one of President Suharto's sons in conjunction with a South Korean firm to produce a national car, which Japan and other complainants say discriminates against other manufacturers.
